curriculumTitle: The Pan-Texas University STEM Scavenger Hunt: Statewide Field Operations
overview: A comprehensive, field-based curriculum designed for in-person campus visits to Texas public universities, specifically tailored for TRIO Upward Bound and UBMS programs. These site-specific modules transform standard college tours into rigorous STEM data collection missions. Students engage with geographic, architectural, and research assets at UT, A&M, UH, UNT, and Texas State systems. The curriculum is fully aligned with 34 CFR Part 645 regulations regarding rigorous math/science curriculum and exposure to postsecondary education.
prerequisites: Completion of Algebra I; basic familiarity with mobile data collection (camera/GPS); signed field trip permission slips including liability waivers compliant with 2 CFR 200.447.

fieldTrips.name: University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) - Richardson
fieldTrips.location: 800 W Campbell Rd, Richardson, TX 75080 (Dallas County)
fieldTrips.description: A high-tech campus located in the Telecom Corridor, focusing on Computer Science and Engineering.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Direct application of the 'Richardson Tech-Corridor Cipher' module.

fieldTrips.name: University of North Texas (UNT) - Denton
fieldTrips.location: 1155 Union Cir, Denton, TX 76203 (Accessible from Tarrant/Dallas)
fieldTrips.description: A major research university known for the intersection of Green Chemistry and Music Engineering.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Site for the 'Green Chemistry & Acoustics Audit' module.

fieldTrips.name: University of Texas at Arlington (UTA)
fieldTrips.location: 701 S Nedderman Dr, Arlington, TX 76019 (Tarrant County)
fieldTrips.description: A conveniently located Tier 1 research university for DFW-based TRIO programs.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Ideal location for the 'Universal Regional Campus' module focusing on Civil Engineering and Nursing.

fieldTrips.name: Texas A&M University - College Station
fieldTrips.description: The state's land-grant flagship, focusing on Agriculture and Mechanical Engineering.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Site for the 'College Station Logistics Challenge' module.

activities.title: Module: UT Austin (The 40 Acres Topography Audit)
activities.description: A site-specific audit of the University of Texas at Austin. Students navigate the distinct elevation changes of the '40 Acres' to analyze civil engineering challenges, focusing on the Dell Medical School bridge infrastructure and the LEED Gold certified Student Activity Center.
learningObjectives: Calculate the 'slope percent' of the walkway leading from the stadium to the main mall.
Locate the Gates Computer Science Complex and identify the 'Bridge' connecting the North and South distinct buildings.
Photograph specific research posters in the Engineering Education and Research Center (EERC).
teks: 111.43 (c)(3): Mathematical Models - Collect and analyze geometric data.

brief: Define perimeter: MLK Blvd to Dean Keeton.
Assign EERC and Turtle Pond tasks.
detailed: Pre-Visit: Drop students at the Welcome Center. Clearly define the safety perimeter.
Briefing: Instruct students that UT Austin has significant grade changes. Accessibility and ADA compliance is the theme.
Task 1: Direct students to the EERC to photograph the exposed HVAC systems (architectural transparency).
Task 2: Have students find the Turtle Pond (Biology) and photograph the species marker.
Start at the UT Tower. Take a selfie with the tower visible to timestamp your start.
Navigate to the Cockrell School of Engineering. Find the 'floating staircase' in the EERC. Estimate its load-bearing capacity.
Locate the Perry-Casta√±eda Library (PCL). Find the STEM tutoring floor. Photograph the operating hours.
Find a wheelchair ramp near the 'Six Pack' (South Mall). Calculate the rise-over-run. Is it 1:12 ratio compliant?
Return to the bus pickup zone on Robert Dedman Drive.

allowableServices: Exposure to the range of career options available
Mentoring (via interaction with campus tour guides)
allowableCosts: Transportation (2 CFR 200.475) - Charter bus to Austin.
trioCompliance.justification: A compliant Campus Visit to a Flagship institution. The curriculum adds necessary academic rigor (Math/Science data collection) to justify the cost beyond a standard recreational tour.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.430 - Compensation for personal services (Staff time)

stemConnections.science: Biology (Ecology of the Turtle Pond/Waller Creek).
stemConnections.engineering: Civil Engineering (Slope/ADA compliance) and Structural Engineering (EERC).

activities.title: Module: Texas A&M (The College Station Logistics Challenge)
activities.description: A navigation-heavy module specific to the massive Texas A&M College Station campus. Students focus on Agricultural Science and Mechanical Engineering, optimizing routes between the 'West Campus' (Ag/Bio) and the 'Main Campus' (Engineering) to simulate logistics efficiency.
learningObjectives: Optimize a travel route using graph theory logic.
Identify and photograph specific agricultural research plots at the Leach Teaching Gardens.
Calculate the structural geometry of the Century Tree or Albritton Bell Tower.
teks: 130.2 (c)(4): Advanced Animal Science - Identify research facilities.
111.44 (c)(4): Advanced Quantitative Reasoning - Network and graph problems.
texasStemStandards: Domain 3: STEM Education and Work-Based Learning

detailed: Pre-Visit: Identify the pedestrian tunnel connecting West and Main campus.
Briefing: Explain that A&M is the largest campus by acreage in Texas. Time management is the primary learning outcome.
Task 1: Challenge students to find the 'Zachry Engineering Education Complex'.
Task 2: Visit the Leach Teaching Gardens. Find a drought-resistant plant and record its Latin name.

brief: Start at MSC (No walking on grass).
detailed: Start at the Memorial Student Center (MSC). Do not walk on the grass.
Navigate to the underpass connecting to West Campus. Measure the time it takes to walk from MSC to the Ag buildings.
Find the 'Bonfire Memorial'. Take a respectful photo and read the engineering history of the collapse.
Locate the Nuclear Science Center signage. Take a photo.
Return to the rendezvous point within 90 minutes.

allowableServices: Assistance in course selection (viewing academic buildings)
Education or counseling services designed to improve financial and economic literacy
allowableCosts: Meals (2 CFR 200.432) - Per diem or group meal allowable.
trioCompliance.justification: Focuses heavily on Agricultural and Mechanical engineering locations. The navigational challenge fulfills the Math/Science rigor required for UBMS site visits.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b) - UBMS focus on Math/Science

collegePathways: BS Plant and Environmental Soil Science

activities.title: Module: University of Houston (The Third Ward Energy Circuit)
activities.description: Specific to the University of Houston. This module focuses on Chemical Engineering, Optometry, and Architecture. Students explore the 'Powerhouse' campus, noting its proximity to the energy corridor and analyzing mid-century modern architecture.
learningObjectives: Locate the Cullen College of Engineering and identify distinct engineering disciplines.
Analyze the geometry of campus fountains for flow rate estimation.
Find the College of Optometry and identify the clinic entrance.

brief: Visit Student Center South for Skyline view.
detailed: Pre-Visit: Drop off at the Welcome Center garage.
Task 1: Instruct students to find the Ezekiel Cullen building (Main Administration).
Task 2: Direct students to the Student Center South for the 'Skyline' view of downtown Houston (Urban Planning).
Start at the Cullen Family Plaza Fountains. Estimate the height of the water jets.
Navigate to the Science and Research 1 building. Find the 'Periodic Table' display.
Locate the TDECU Stadium. Calculate the seating capacity based on the placards.
Find the College of Architecture. Photograph the 'green roof'.
Return to the Student Center.

allowableServices: Exposure to the range of career options available (Petrochemical/Medical)
trioCompliance.justification: Emphasizes Chemical Engineering and Health Sciences (Optometry), aligning with UBMS priorities.

activities.title: Module: University of North Texas (The Green Chemistry & Acoustics Audit)
activities.description: Specific to UNT in Denton. This module highlights the university's dual strengths in Music (Acoustics) and Materials Science/Green Chemistry.
learningObjectives: Analyze the Murchison Performing Arts Center for acoustic isolation.
Locate the Environmental Science building to identify 'LEED' certification markers.
Identify the shuttle route to Discovery Park.
texasStemStandards: Domain 3: STEM Education and Work-Based Learning

brief: Explain Discovery Park vs Main Campus.
detailed: Pre-Visit: Note that Engineering is located at 'Discovery Park' (requires bus), while Sciences are on Main Campus.
Task 1: Have students measure ambient noise levels near the Music building vs. the Library.
Task 2: Locate the 'Mean Green' stadium wind turbines.
Start at the Library Mall. Measure the decibel level.
Navigate to the Life Sciences Complex. Find a poster about 'Plant Biology'.
Walk to the Murchison Performing Arts Center. Observe the curved roof and explain its acoustic function.
Find a 'We Mean Green' recycling station. What items are accepted?
Return to the Union.

allowableServices: Exposure to the range of career options available
trioCompliance.justification: UNT provides a unique intersection of Physics (Acoustics) and Environmental Science, fulfilling STEM exposure requirements.

activities.title: Module: UT Dallas (The Richardson Tech-Corridor Cipher)
activities.description: Specific to UTD in Richardson. Focuses heavily on Computer Science, Robotics, and Cognitive Science. Students interact with the high-tech aesthetic of the campus and industry partners.
learningObjectives: Interact with autonomous food delivery robots ('Tobor').
texasStemStandards: Domain 3: STEM Education and Work-Based Learning

detailed: Pre-Visit: Brief students on UTD's reputation as a 'nerd-cool' campus with a heavy CS focus.
Task 1: Have students find a 'Tobor' (food robot). Observe how it navigates obstacles.
Task 2: Direct students to the ECS (Engineering/Computer Science) complex.
Start at the Plinth (Main Fountain).
Locate a 'Tobor' delivery robot. Take a selfie. Observe sensors (Lidar/Camera).
Navigate to the Engineering and Computer Science (ECS) building. Count the dual-monitor workstations.
Find the 'Atecs' building (Arts and Technology). Find a poster for an Animation or Game Design event.
Return to the bus near the Visitor Center.

allowableServices: Exposure to the range of career options available (Tech/CS)
trioCompliance.justification: Heavily skewed toward Math and Computer Science, leveraging specific industrial connections to the telecom/tech sector.

activities.title: Module: Universal Regional Campus (The Community Resource Scan)
activities.description: Flexible module for regional universities (e.g., UTA, SFA, TWU, Tarleton). Emphasizes Health Sciences, Education, and regional Industry connections.
learningObjectives: Locate the main Science or Nursing building and identify one major lab facility.
Find the Student Success Center or Trio Office.
Identify the primary industry partner of the university.

detailed: Pre-Visit: Customize the 'Target Industry' based on the specific campus (e.g., Nursing for TWU, Space Science for UTRGV).
Task 1: Direct students to the library to find the STEM reference section.
Task 2: Locate the financial aid office.
Start at the Administration Building.
Navigate to the Library. Find a study room and photograph the booking system/QR code.
Locate the largest Science, Nursing, or Engineering building. Read the directory and list three departments.
Find a statute or monument unique to the campus history. Photograph it.
Return to the transport vehicle.

allowableServices: Exposure to the range of career options available
trioCompliance.justification: Ensures students in all regions of Texas have access to structured campus visits.
